image.altText: A man and a woman inside a camper van.

props.synopsis: Northern Territory police have announced a new $500,000 reward for information that leads to the discovery of Peter Falconio's body, more than 20 years after his murder.

title.children: Police offer $500k reward in bid to find Peter Falconio's remains

image.altText: A full street with people marching with flags and signs, one says: liberation freedom restitution.

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has been urged to convene national cabinet to address First Nations deaths in custody and incarceration, as justice leaders, experts and community voices meet today in Alice Springs.

title.children: First Nations leaders urge PM to convene national cabinet on prison crisis

image.altText: Andrew Hastie sits for an interview in a room. He has a serious expression.

props.synopsis: The Coalition frontbencher is also urging the Labor government explain what role Australia might play backing US combat operations launched from this country.

title.children: Hastie demands answer about US military's growing presence in Australia

image.altText: Two people in a car.

props.synopsis: Finke Desert Race co-driver Bernie Webb says a safety mechanism kept him and his driver safe after they lost control at 160kph.

title.children: Desert racers release cabin video of high-speed, airborne crash

image.altText: An adult white woman with long blonde hair and a black coat standing in front of a power point presentation

props.synopsis: New resources launched by Australia's Education Research Organisation will arm all teachers with the skills to teach writing.

title.children: 'Wasn't part of the syllabus': Australia's 30-year fail in teaching writing

image.altText: A female doctor carrying a stethoscope.

props.synopsis: Medical students say a rural work program meant to solve doctor shortages is pushing some to abandon their careers and others to pay their way out.

title.children: Medical graduates question rural relocation work scheme

image.altText: Tucker Carlson speaks into a microphone at a podium.

props.synopsis: Former Fox News host Tucker Carlson claims the network's Australian boss, Lachlan Murdoch, encouraged him to run for US president to thwart Donald Trump's return to the White House.

title.children: 'The Murdochs really hate Trump': Carlson says Fox CEO urged election run

image.altText: Two men in suits hold a framed wooden fish in front of a wood-panelled wall

props.synopsis: Australia will provide sweeping support for Solomon Islands ahead of a key leaders meeting in September.

title.children: Australia to provide $20 million package to Solomon Islands for key forum

image.altText: A sign on a brick wall reads 'Western Sydney University', in the distance are some large buildings.

props.synopsis: The Australian Sanctions Office has investigated an event held on the campus of Western Sydney University as possibly breaching sanctions placed on PressTV, Iran's state media outlet.

title.children: Uni cops sanctions warning after Iran state media attended event on campus

image.altText: A woman is seen from the shoulders up standing in front of a flag

props.synopsis: In a "state of panic" the ABC bowed to pressure from pro-Israel lobbyists and fired radio presenter Antoinette Lattouf to avoid complaints and attention. Ironically the broadcaster earned more scrutiny in court.

title.children: The irony at the heart of the Antoinette Lattouf case for the ABC

image.altText: A man looks at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: A mixed session on Wall Street is likely to send Australian stocks lower, while oil prices rise, snapping three straight sessions of losses. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: Nvidia hits record high, oil prices gain

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Kylie Moore-Gilbert says Iranians fear they're about to pay the price from a vengeful regime
Shell denies BP takeover talks after WSJ report

image.altText: Aerial view of cleared land

props.synopsis: A Victorian sawmill has harvested wood from endangered mountain ash forests and sold it to Domino's as woodchips to smoke meat for pizzas.

title.children: Domino's pizzas allegedly cooked using woodchips from endangered possum habitat

image.altText: Silver gas pipelines run along ground with trees behidn them

props.synopsis: Australian households are using less gas, with some getting off the fuel entirely. And that changes the whole business model for gas pipelines in a way that could see consumers paying more.

title.children: As gas use declines, those remaining could foot bigger bills

image.altText: Woman with blond hair and black shirt standing in front of house

props.synopsis: Montana Adams lost everything in a horrific house fire. Her landlord tried to claim $15,000 in compensation after accusing her of starting it.

title.children: Mother of eight blamed by landlord for accidental fire that gutted house

image.altText: Watercolour illustration of aboriginal child riding a 44 gallon drum tied between two trees.

props.synopsis: Young stockman Wylie Oscar went missing in outback Western Australia three years ago. His case remains a mystery

title.children: Where is Wylie Oscar? Behind the search for the missing man

image.altText: An aerial photo shows a series of five dams surrounded by grass and trees.

props.synopsis: Despite a moratorium on building new dams in the Mount Lofty Ranges since 2013, landholders have built about 400 and enlarged about 300 without approval.

title.children: Satellite photos reveal hundreds of illegal dams in SA region

image.altText: Donald Trump shakes the hand of Volodymyr Zelenskyy as they sit beside each other in a room.

props.synopsis: Defence Minister Richard Marles announces at the NATO summit that Australia will deploy ADF troops to Europe to help protect international humanitarian aid for Ukraine.

title.children: Trump says US may provide more missiles to Ukraine after meeting Zelenskyy

image.altText: A man with a black jacket and a walker stands next to a woman in a black jumper and a walker

props.synopsis: A not-for-profit organisation says increasing administrative costs linked to the federal government's aged care reforms have left it with no choice but to stop providing transport to social outings for residents.

title.children: Aged care reforms leave elderly cut off from social outings

image.altText: Firefighters battle a factory fire in the early hours of the morning.

props.synopsis: Firefighters have battled two factory fires across Melbourne overnight, with at least a dozen crews called to one of the fires in Melbourne's south-east.

title.children: Police investigating suspicious factory fires across Melbourne overnight

image.altText: People with bags wait in a line

props.synopsis: More than 600 metres of cable along train tracks has been stolen in northern France, wrecking havoc for travel between London and Paris.

title.children: Cable theft in France disrupts train travel between London and Paris

image.altText: A family looks out onto planes on the tarmac at an airport.

props.synopsis: In the days after the Air India crash, it was revealed that warnings had been issued about some of the airline's other planes. So, why isn't information like this always publicly available? And how can we know which airlines are safe?

title.children: What's the safest airline, and why the answer might not be straightforward

image.altText: A close-up of a woman's face looking into the camera with a neutral expression. She has long grey hair and blue eyes.

props.synopsis: A major hospital's infectious diseases unit will be moved across a main road, after the doctors' union lost an appeal to stop the relocation.

title.children: Concerns raised for HIV care after tribunal dismisses bid to halt infection unit move

image.altText: An underwater photo of three seahorses, one is yellow, one is black and one is cream coloured.

props.synopsis: White's Seahorse is found in seagrass beds along Australia's east coast, but little is known of their numbers in Queensland.

title.children: Population survey of 'charismatic little fish' underway in Queensland

image.altText: A silhouetted corrections officer walks down a cell corridor in a prison.

props.synopsis: As figures shown in parliament outline the level of overcrowding in Western Australia's prisons, the Justice Department says increased family and domestic violence charges are a factor.

title.children: Up to four inmates being crammed into a cell in WA prisons

image.altText: a child shovels sand into a plastic bucket

props.synopsis: The state government has committed to implement a number of reforms, including a new independent regulator, following a review into the early childhood sector by the former deputy NSW Ombudsman.

title.children: NSW to introduce independent early childhood regulator following review into sector

image.altText: Australian currency is seen next to a wages graph

props.synopsis: Consumer prices rose 2.1 per cent over the year to May, down from 2.4 per cent the previous month, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

title.children: Inflation eases back more than expected in May

image.altText: Three poker machines in a club with brightly coloured screens showing different gambling games, with three empty stools in front

props.synopsis: Mandatory pre-commitment cards for poker machine players, aimed to limit the harm for problem gamblers, won't be introduced in Tasmania unless other states and territories agree to a national approach on the issue, the Premier Rockliff says.

title.children: Pokies pre-commitment card won't go ahead without 'national approach'

image.altText: ShamarQH

props.synopsis: Travis Head gets very lucky, the West Indies have butter fingers in Barbados and Shamar Joseph picks up where he left off on an eventful first day's play at Kensington Oval in the first Test. Here's the five quick hits.

title.children: Five quick hits: Trav's controversial lucky break and Shamar shines again

image.altText: A large pile of metal objects next to construction equipment and a man in a hard hat

props.synopsis: The NSW government has reaffirmed its plan for a state-of-the-art secondary school in the state's far west, allocating more than $55 million to rebuild Willyama High School after a mould outbreak.

title.children: Mouldy Broken Hill high school rebuild closer after state budget

image.altText: A man from UNICEF in a bulletproof vest sits with a 13-year-old boy from Gaza with bandages across his torso.

props.synopsis: As a child dies from shrapnel wounds to his stomach and Israel denies starvation is occurring in Gaza the UN's aid urgency issues a warning that kids may soon die of thirst.

title.children: Thirteen-year-old Abed died weeks after shrapnel ripped through him in Gaza

image.altText: A shed and cars submerged in floodwaters, trees in the background.

props.synopsis: Many across south-east Queensland are still assessing the damage wrought by ex-Tropical Cyclone Alfred earlier this year.

title.children: Clean-up continues three months after Alfred

image.altText: A digital drawing of Erin Patterson wearing a pink shirt

props.synopsis: Justice Christopher Beale's directions to the jury in Ms Patterson's triple-murder trial enter their second day at the Latrobe Valley Law Courts in the regional Victorian town of Morwell.

title.children: Judge in Erin Patterson trial continues final instructions to jury

image.altText: A man, smiling, wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: A jury finds a man who stabbed a young Melbourne doctor 11 times after a home invasion guilty of murder.

title.children: Jury finds man guilty of murdering doctor Ashley Gordon

image.altText: A loaded container ship sails off from a container terminal across calm blue waters.

props.synopsis: Australia has an opportunity to become the world's dominant provider of green shipping fuel, says Superpower Institute chair Rod Sims.

title.children: Australia should dominate supply of green shipping fuel, says Rod Sims
